Award.AwardTitle: SG: Exploring the Impact of Model (Mis) Specification on Empirical Divergence-Time Estimates
Award.AbstractNarration:
Phylogenetic trees - estimates of the evolutionary relationships among species - have become central to virtually all areas of research in systematics, evolutionary biology, ecology, molecular biology, and epidemiology because of the essential and explicit historical perspectives they provide. Phylogenies have extended the branches of their influence from the scientific to the public realm, informing decisions regarding the surveillance and monitoring of pathogens, vaccine design, and conservation priorities. Although many phylogenies are based on molecular sequence data (DNA) collected from extant species (or strains), these trees can also provide information regarding the absolute or relative branching times within a lineage. This temporal information is critical to many questions, such as inferring when a virulent strain of a virus first arose and estimating how quickly it is changing. These considerations have motivated the development of a large number of mathematical models for inferring the time scale of evolutionary trees. This project seeks to assess the reliability of these mathematical models using empirical datasets, and will inform researchers and public alike on the best practices for using these methods. Undergraduates recruited through the University of California Historically Black Colleges and Universities initiative and the US Davis Initiative for Maximizing Student Diversity will be trained in statistical phylogenetic methods and bioinformatics. All software developed will be distributed freely under open-source licenses. The researcher will also develop a new, stand-alone workshop and associated teaching materials on Bayesian divergence-time estimation methods to be used broadly, including by researchers who do not work directly in phylogenetic research.

The primary objective of this research is to explore the statistical behavior of Bayesian methods for estimating species divergence times in an empirical setting. This main goal will be achieved by applying all currently implemented relaxed-clock models and calibration methods to a large sample of empirical datasets to: (1) reveal the extent to which divergence-time estimates are sensitive to the specified relaxed-clock model/calibration method; (2) explore the relative influence of the three primary model components - branch-rate priors, node-age priors, and calibration approaches - on divergence-time estimates; (3) assess the relative fit of the pool of candidate relaxed-clock models to real data using robust Bayesian model-comparison methods; and (4) develop analytical protocols and implement pipelines that automate the efficient exploration of relaxed-clock model space for empirical analyses. Facilitating more careful model selection will improve our ability to estimate divergence times, which, in turn, will broadly benefit scientific and broader communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phylogenies that include relative or absolute temporal information provide an explicit historical perspective that critically informs research in a vast and growing number of scientific disciplines. Increasingly, divergence times are inferred in a Bayesian statistical framework under so-called 'relaxed-clock models' that accommodate variation in substitution rates among lineages. Relaxed-clock models are comprised of three main components: (1) a site model describes how the nucleotide sequences evolved over the branches of the tree; (2) a branch-rate prior model specifies how substitution rates vary across branches of the tree, and; (3) a node-age prior model specifies the distribution of tree topologies and the speciation times in the tree. All possible combinations of these three components therefore defines the entire space of possible relaxed-clock models.

Remarkable progress in the development of relaxed-clock models for estimating divergence times is one of the major success stories in modern biology. The diversity of increasingly complex (and hopefully realistic) relaxed-clock models has the potential to improve divergence-time estimates, but demands careful (and computationally expensive) comparison among candidate models in order to assess their fit to a given empirical dataset. Moreover, the statistical behavior of these models has not been carefully explored by simulation, so the relative merits (and pitfalls) of alternative relaxed-clock models are poorly understood. This state of affairs is particularly worrisome, as the vast majority of empirical studies forgo formal selection among the many candidate relaxed-clock models, and instead simply assume a single (and arbitrary) model. The consequences of this emerging convention--both for divergence-time estimates and also for the inferences based on these trees--are potentially profound but presently unknown.

This NSF-funded project addressed these critical issues by exploring the statistical behavior of Bayesian methods for estimating species divergence times in an empirical setting over two project phases. In the first project phase, we collected and curated 53 published datasets, and completed analyses of these datasets under a range of partitioned-data models, which consumed more than 4.6 million compute hours. These analyses revealed that the choice of partitioned-data model strongly impacts estimates of the phylogeny and divergence times, and (distressingly) demonstrated that existing methods for selecting partitioned-data models lead to poor model choices for most datasets. We have developed a novel Bayesian model-averaging approach that allows the phylogeny and other model parameters to be estimated while integrating over all possible partitioned- data models, which we implemented in our freely-available, user-friendly software package, AutoParts. In the second project phase, we: (1) developed more realistic node-age prior models that allow rates of speciation and extinction to vary through time and/or across lineages of the phylogeny; (2) performed analyses of the empirical datasets to explore the impact of node-age prior models on divergence-time estimates, and; (3) developed new methods (and assessed the statistical behavior of two existing methods) for inferring rates of lineage diversification that focus on parameters of the node-age prior models. We have implemented these new methods in in our freely-available, user-friendly package, TESS.

Overall, this NSF project provided critical support for the development of statistical and computational tools that will improve our ability to estimate dated phylogenies, and the resulting increase in our ability to accurately estimate dated phylogenies will, in turn, benefit the myriad scientific disciplines that rely on such phylogenetic information.
